description: From Middle English bulge (“leather bag; hump”), from Old Northern French boulge (“leather bag”), from Late Latin bulga (“leather sack”), from Gaulish *bulga, *bulgos, from Proto-Celtic *bolgos (“sack, bag, stomach”). Cognate with bilge, belly, bellows, budget, French bouge, German Balg, etc. Doublet of budge, and from the same root as belly and bellows. See also budget.

entries.meaning: Something sticking out from a surface; a swelling, protuberant part; a bending outward, especially when caused by pressure.
examples: a bulge in my pocket where I kept my wallet

entries.meaning: The bilge or protuberant part of a cask.
(colloquial) The outline of male genitals visible through clothing.
(figurative) A sudden rise in value or quantity.
examples: A second bulge in prices occurred during September 30 — October 9. The rise of prices up to October 3 was in part apparently a technical adjustment of the markets, a reaction to the preceding decline.

verbs.description: bulge (third-person singular simple present bulges, present participle bulging, simple past and past participle bulged)

examples: The submarine bulged because of the enormous air pressure inside.
He stood six feet tall, with muscular arms bulging out of his black T-shirt.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To bilge, as a ship; to founder.
examples: Fatal to Man! at once all Ocean roars,
And scattered navies bulge on distant shores.
